title.p: Gallery V: Blake's Anagogical Interpretation of the Bible
The Sefirotic Tree

image.caption:
The Sefirotic Tree, showing the positions of the emanations, all linked through a series of canals. The original ten are: Keter (supreme crown); Hokhmah (divine wisdom); Binah (human intelligence); Hesed (grace); Gevurah (strength); Tif'eret (beauty); Netzah (victory); Hod (glory); Yesod (foundation); Malkhut (kingdom). At the top Keter, also known as the Ancient of Days, refers to the unknowable godhead. He is manifested by Hokhmah and Binah. These three, located in the World of Emanation, constitute the divine idea of creation. When the primordial fault occurred, the connection with the idea was severed. To bridge the gap, kabbalists postulated an eleventh Sefirah: Da'at, a distinct mode of knowing, capable of mediating between the empirical rational faculty that governs thought in the corporeal cosmos and the higher intellectual faculties of the spiritual realm.
Image: Eliyak, public domain, via Wikimedia Commons. <﻿https://​commons.​wikimedia.​org/​wiki/​File:​Ktreewnames.​png﻿>.

title.p: Gallery V: Blake's Anagogical Interpretation of the Bible
Human configuration of the Sefirot

image.caption:
Ein Sof, "The Endless," is outside the enclosed space into which the godhead emanated the Sefirot. The male figure has two correspondents: Adam Kadmon, primordial man, the macrocosm; and Adam Rishon, first or created man, the microcosm.
Image: Christian D. Ginsburg, The Kabbalah: Its Doctrines, Development, and Literature (1863; London: Longmans, Green, Reader, and Dyer, 1865), between pp. 16 and 17.
